analyzed: ucitā viśrāma bhūḥ iyam samara vyāpāra khinnasya vīra janasya
translated: This is a suitable resting place for the weary warriors engaged in battle.

original: atra sthitaścāyācitatālavṛntena haricandanacchaṭāśītalenāprayatnasurabhiṇā daśāpariṇāmayogyena sarasīsamīraṇenāmunā gataklamo bhaviṣyati mahārājaḥ
analyzed: atra sthitaḥ ca a yācita tālavṛntena haricandana chaṭā śītalena aprayatna surabhiṇā daśā pariṇāma yogyena sarasī samīraṇena amunā gata klamaḥ bhaviṣyati mahā rājaḥ
translated: And here, the great king, relieved of fatigue by this lake breeze, which is like an unsolicited fan, cool with drops of green sandalwood paste, naturally fragrant, and suitable for the change of state, will rest.

analyzed: lūna ketuḥ ca ayam rathaḥ nivāritaḥ eva pravekṣyati chāyām
translated: And this chariot with its flagstaff cut down will enter the shade unhindered.
Having thus imagined the entry,
Who is there, gentlemen?
Looking around
How is it that there is no one from the retinue here?

original: nūnaṃ tathāvidhasya vṛkodarasya darśanādevaṃvidhasya ca svāminastrāsena śibirasaṃniveśameva praviṣṭaḥ /

translated: Surely, out of fear of seeing such a Vrikodara and such a king, he has entered the camp itself.
Alas, alas!

original: dattvā droṇena pārthādabhayamapi na saṃrakṣitaḥ sindhurājaḥ krūraṃ duḥśāsane 'sminhariṇa iva kṛtaṃ bhīmasenena karma

translated: Having given the Parthas assurance, Drona did not protect the king of the Sindhus. Bhima has done a cruel deed to this Dushasana, like a deer.

original: duḥsādhyāmapyarīṇāṃ laghumiva samare pūrayitvā pratijñāṃ ē nāhaṃ manye sakāmaṃ kurukulavimukhaṃ daivametāvatāpi // / //

Looking at the king.

analyzed: katham adya api na cetanām labhate mahā rājaḥ
translated: How is it that the great king has not yet regained consciousness?

analyzed: bhoḥ kaṣṭam niḥśvasya  mada kalita kareṇu bhajyamāne vipine iva prakaṭa eka śāla śeṣe
translated: Alas! Sighing🔽and with his body emaciated by the burden of grief, like a forest in which a single shala tree remains standing,

analyzed: nanu bho hatavidhe bharata kula vimukha
translated: O cursed Vidura, averse to the Bharata race,

analyzed: akṣatasya gadā pāṇeḥ an ārūḍhasya saṃśayam
translated: of the uninjured one with the mace in his hand, who has not yet mounted (the chariot), there is no doubt.

analyzed: eṣā api bhīmasenasya pratijñā pūryate tvayā
translated: This vow of Bhimasena is being fulfilled by you.
Duryodhana.
Slowly regaining consciousness

analyzed: āḥ śaktiḥ asti durātmanaḥ vṛkodara hatakasya mayi jīvati duryodhane pratijñām pūrayitum
translated: Ah! Does the wicked Vrikodara, the slayer of my brothers, have the power to fulfill his vow against me, Duryodhana, while I am alive?

original: vatsa duḥśāsana na bhetavyaṃ na bhetavyam /
analyzed: vatsa duḥśāsana na bhetavyam na bhetavyam
translated: My son Dushasana, do not fear, do not fear.
I have come here.

Charioteer:

Duryodhana:

translated: Having descended from the chariot, with pride and intention
it has been done by the delay in the time of going by chariot.
Charioteer:
With embarrassment and compassion
Please pardon, please pardon, O long-lived one.
Duryodhana:

translated: Fie on the chariot, charioteer! What is the use of the chariot?🔽I, Duryodhana, who move only in the clash of battles with enemies,

translated: I descend to the battlefield with only the mace as my companion.
Charioteer:
O long-lived one, it is so.
What doubt is there?
Duryodhana:

analyzed: yadi evam kim evam bhāṣase paśya
translated: If it is so, why do you speak thus? See.

Charioteer:
Falling at his feet with compassion,
I make this request.

translated: O long-lived one, you who have fulfilled your vow, you must now turn back, you evil-souled one, with Vrikodara slain.
Therefore I say this.
Duryodhana.
Falling suddenly on the ground

analyzed: hā vatsa duḥśāsana hā mad ājñā virodhita pāṇḍava hā vikrama eka rasa hā mad aṅka durlalita hā arāti kula gaja ghaṭā mṛga indra hā yuvarāja kva asi
translated: Oh my son Duhshasana, oh you who disobeyed my orders and killed the Pandavas, oh you who take delight only in valor, oh you who played roughly in my lap, oh you who are like a lion among the herd of elephants of the Atikula, oh prince, where are you?
Give me an answer.
Having sighed thus, he falls into a swoon.
Charioteer.
O king, be calm, be calm.
Duryodhana.
Having regained consciousness, sighing

analyzed: muktaḥ yatheṣṭam upabhoga sukheṣu nā eva tvam hi mayā na vṛthak agrajena
translated: You were not indulged by me in the pleasures of enjoyment as you wished, nor was my elder brother in vain,

translated: But, my son, I was the cause of your misfortune, and I did not protect you when I was ordered to do so.

Charioteer.
O long-lived one, be calm, be calm.
Duryodhana.
Fie on you, charioteer, what have you done?
I was protected by my brother Duhshasana, who was always to be protected, who was a child, who followed ignorance,
and who was killed by the Pāñcāla prince.
Charioteer.

Duryodhana.
O charioteer, you have done a terrible deed.

analyzed: tasya eva pāṇḍava paśoḥ anuja dviṣaḥ me kṣodaiḥ gadā aśani kṛtaiḥ na vibodhitaḥ smi

Sighing, looking at the sky

analyzed: nanu bho hatavidhe kṛpā virahita bharata kula vimukha
translated: Alas, O cursed fate, devoid of compassion, averse to the Bharata dynasty

Charioteer.
Evil is at peace, evil is at peace.
O great king, what is this?
Duryodhana.

analyzed: ghātita aśeṣa bandhoḥ me kim rājyena jayena vā

Sundaraka:

Circling and looking

I will search elsewhere.
Looking ahead and circling a little

translated: These are indeed many brave men, the Sanghadasa brothers, who are seen.
I will go there and ask. Approaching

Looking elsewhere

translated: This group of people, who have lost many relatives and are in a state of grief, are crying out, having seen this empty seat.

translated: Let it be.

Looking everywhere

Whom shall I question?🔽Let it be.

translated: the king of the entire earth-circle, the great king Duṣyanta, is being sought.

Looking elsewhere🔽There, that one with a face resembling a thousand suns shining together,
who is surrounded by the splendor of the forest fire of his own valor,

translated: I think it must be the place where the great king Duryodhana rests.
Until I find out.
Approaching, seeing, and sighing

translated: Noble ones, have you seen the great king Duryodhana, accompanied by his charioteer, in this place or not?
How is it that no one counsels him?
Well then.

analyzed: eteṣām baddha parikarāṇām puruṣāṇām samūhaḥ dṛśyate
translated: A group of men with bound retinues is seen.
Going there, I will ask.

They do not know that.
Well then.
I will search elsewhere.

analyzed: hā ati karuṇam khalu atra vartate

Well done, mother of a hero, well done.

analyzed: anyasmin api janmāntare nihata putrakā bhaviṣyasi
translated: In another birth also, you will have sons who are not killed.
Let it be.
I will search elsewhere.

translated: This other group of warriors, with their bodies struck by many blows and without having had their wounds bandaged, weep, having approached this empty seat and horse.

Well, they also do not know.
Let it be.
Having gone elsewhere, I will ask.

translated: How is it that people, experiencing misfortune in every state, are confused by their aversion to fate?
Whom shall I ask about this?
Whom shall I reproach?
Let it be.
I will search for him myself.
Let it be.

with anger

original: kvāsau dhārtarāṣṭrasakhā puṇyajanāpasado yenāryasya mahāṃścittavibhramaḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: kva asau dhārtarāṣṭra sakhā puṇyajana apasadaḥ yena āryasya mahān citta vibhramaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: Where is that friend of Dhritarashtra's son, that outcast of good people, by whom this noble one was greatly deceived?
Krishna:
That wicked one has been seized by Nākula.

analyzed: tat kathaya mahā rāja kim asmāt param samīhitam saṃpādayāmi
translated: So tell me, great king, what more I can do to accomplish your wishes.
Yudhi Shthira:

original: evaṃ puṇḍarīkākṣa na kiṃcinna dadāti bhagavānprasannaḥ /
analyzed: evam puṇḍarīkākṣa na kiṃcid na dadāti bhagavān prasannaḥ
translated: Thus, lotus-eyed one, the blessed one, when pleased, gives nothing less than everything.

analyzed: aham tu puruṣa sādhāraṇayā buddhyā saṃtuṣyāmi
translated: But I am content with a human-like understanding.

analyzed: na khalu atas param abhyarthayitum kṣamaḥ
translated: I am not able to ask for anything more.
Let the king see.

original: krodhāndhaiḥ sakalaṃ hataṃ ripukulaṃ pañcākṣatāste vayaṃ pāñcālyā mama durnayopajanitastīrṇo nikārārṇavaḥ
analyzed: krodha andhaiḥ sakalam hatam ripu kulam pañca akṣatāḥ te vayam pāñcālyāḥ mama durnaya upajanitaḥ tīrṇaḥ nikāra arṇavaḥ
translated: The entire enemy clan was killed by us, blinded with anger; we five are safe; the ocean of insult caused by my bad policy towards the Panchāla princess is crossed.

original: tvaṃ devaḥ puruṣottamaḥ sukṛtinaṃ māmādṛto bhāṣase ē kiṃ nāmānyadataḥ paraṃ bhagavato yāce prasannādaham // / //
analyzed: tvam devaḥ puruṣottamaḥ sukṛtinam mām ādṛtaḥ bhāṣase ē kim nāma anyat atas param bhagavataḥ yāce prasannāt aham  /
translated: You are the god, the best of men, and you address me, a virtuous person, with respect. What else can I ask of the Blessed One, if you are pleased with me?

analyzed: tathā api prītataraḥ ced bhagavān tat idam astu
translated: Nevertheless, if the Blessed One is even more pleased, let this be so:

original: akṛpaṇamarukśrāntaṃ jīvyājjanaḥ puruṣāyuṣaṃ bhavatu bhagavanbhaktirdvaitaṃ vinā puruṣottame
analyzed: akṛpaṇam aruj śrāntam jīvyāt janaḥ puruṣa āyuṣam bhavatu bhagavan bhaktiḥ dvaitam vinā puruṣottame
translated: May people live to a ripe old age, free from poverty, disease, or fatigue. O Blessed One, may there be devotion to the Supreme Being without duality.

original: dayitabhuvano vidvadbandhurguṇeṣu viśeṣavi ē tsatatasukṛtī bhūyādbhūpaḥ prasādhitamaṇḍalaḥ // / //
analyzed: dayita bhuvanaḥ vidvas bandhuḥ guṇeṣu t satata sukṛtī bhūyāt bhūpaḥ prasādhita maṇḍalaḥ
translated: May the king, dear to the people, a friend to the learned, distinguished in virtues, always virtuous, be victorious, with his dominion well-established.
And moreover:

original: avanimavanipālāḥ pāntu vṛṣṭiṃ vidhattāṃ jagati jaladharālī śasyapūrṇāstu bhūmiḥ
analyzed: avanim avanipālāḥ pāntu vṛṣṭim vidhattām jagati jaladhara ālī śasya pūrṇā astu bhūmiḥ
translated: May the kings protect the earth, may the rows of rain-clouds shower rain on the earth, may the earth be full of crops,

original: tvayi muranarakārau bhaktiradvaitayogā ē dbhavatu mama sudīrghaṃ havyamaśnantu devāḥ // / //
analyzed: tvayi mura nara kārau bhaktiḥ advaita yogā ā bhavatu mama su dīrgham havyam aśnantu devāḥ  /
translated: may I have devotion to you, O Krishna, the destroyer of Mura and ignorance, with the yoga of non-dualism, for a very long time, may the gods partake of the offerings.
Krishna:
So be it.
Thus all depart.
Thus ends the sixth act.
This drama called The Destruction of the Venis is complete.

original: idaṃ ca vidagdhasnigdhaviyogadurmanasā vipralapitaṃ tena kavinā /
analyzed: idam ca vidagdha snigdha viyoga durmanasā vipralapitam tena kavinā
translated: And this was spoken by that poet, who was despondent due to the separation of his beloved and clever wife.

original: kāvyālāpasubhāṣitavyasaninaste rājahaṃsā gatā🔽stā goṣṭhyaḥ kṣayamāgatā guṇalavaślāghyāstu vācaḥ satām /
analyzed: kāvya ālāpa subhāṣita vyasaninaḥ te rājahaṃsā gatā  stāḥ goṣṭhyaḥ kṣayam āgatāḥ guṇa lava ślāghyāḥ tu vācaḥ satām
translated: Those royal swans, addicted to poetic conversation and good sayings, have gone.🔽Those assemblies have come to an end, but the words of the good, praiseworthy for their mere trace of merit,

analyzed: sa alaṃkāra rasa prasanna madhura ākārāḥ kavīnām giraḥ
translated: The sweet-natured words of poets, pleasing with their ornaments and rasa,

original: prāptā nāśamayaṃ tu bhūmivalaye jīyātprabandho mahān //
analyzed: prāptāḥ nāśam ayam tu bhūmi valaye jīyāt prabandhaḥ mahān
translated: Have been destroyed, but may this great work long endure in this world.
